devel.commit_message: Correct typo in ssm -h for the mount command

docs: list used environment variables in one place

Make it clear what env vars ssm uses.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

tests: 018 - remove unnecessary check for crypt

This is migrate test, not crypt test, so we don't have to test
what version of encryption was used; Hardcoded value like the removed
line leads to trouble when the system default changes.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

tests: add bash test skipping capabilities

Not all tests can be run all the time. If e.g. a required tool for some
backend is missing, it is better to skip the test and mark it so, rather
than fail, leaving the developer to search why.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

bashtests: allow testing of system-wide ssm

This patch allows us to test the installed, system-wide ssm, instead of
the local version.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

unittests: better multipath message on fail

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: verify requirements before committing to any action

Check if all used backends have their requirements before making any
changes to storage. This prevents situations where ssm e.g. aborts with
missing cryptsetup after it already created LVM pool and volumes.

The verification is added to operations that can require more than one
backend and we want to be sure that they do not fail in the middle. For
other operations like check, there is no penalty in discovering the
missing dependency on the fly, so we keep them simpler.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

release 1.4

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

bashtests: add --units h to lvs/pvs/vgs

Use --units h to avoid '<' rounding indicator that can appear in the
default unit.

From man pvs:
--units r|R|h|H|b|B|s|S|k|K|m|M|g|G|t|T|p|P|e|E
   All sizes are output in these units: human-(r)eadable with '<'
   rounding indicator, (h)uman-readable, (b)ytes, (s)ectors, [snip]

The values should not change, but if there is some small
platform-specific difference that needs rounding, it won't break the tests.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

---

Lukas, do you think that this is a good approach? Or should we change it
to --units k and demand exact sizes?

Thanks,
Jan

tests: enhance 016-multipath.sh test

We can't do much, because of the lvm filter configuration used by ssm tests,
but at least something...

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

tests: do not use info command in multipath test

There is no reason for using it ATM.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

multipath: disallow multipath as default backend

As multipath is a read-only, device-only backend, it makes no sense
to use it as a default backend (-b multipath). Do the same thing we
already do for md backend and remove it from valid options to prevent
misunderstandings and errors.

Resolves: rhbz#1685019

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

multipath: allow any string as mp dev id

The regexes for multipath devices allowed only for hex strings, but in
some cases, any string can appear there. This patch changes the regexes
to detect such devices too.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

bashtests: test for delay in detecting xfs resize

A test for issue rbhz#1664652, where ssm had a delay in detecting
changed sizes for xfs partitions.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: fix sizes in xfs_get_info for mounted devices

ssm usually works with sizes in kb, but statvfs reports in bytes,
so the values we got for mounted xfs were off by an order. A simple
division by 1024 brings that into order.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: correctly use real devname in xfs_get_info

The dict from get_mounts() is indexed by real device name
(get_real_device() in get_mountinfo/get_mounts_old), but we were using
arbitrary name in xfs_get_info().  Use the real dev name instead.

RHBZ 1664652

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssm: use LC_ALL=C when running tools from ssm

Previously, we used LC_NUMERIC, but if LC_ALL is set by the user/system,
then LC_NUMERIC is ignored, leading to issues with locales with
different decimal delimiter literal than a dot. So, set LC_ALL instead
of LC_NUMERIC.

This forces other localized things like error messages to English. But
because ssm does not have translations, we can have errors reported by
tools (like lvm) within ssm always in English as well.

Resolves: rhbz#1679587
Resolves: rhbz#1679591
Resolves: #7 (github)

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>
Reviewed-by: Lukas Czerner <lczerner@redhat.com>

ssmlib: fix pwquality support for python3

The pwquality.PWQError has some differences between Python 2 and 3. The
semantics for P3 works for P2, but not the other way around, so use
ex.args instead of a simple ex.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

unittest: add a test for listing with xfs

This is a regression test to ensure that we won't use xfs_db on a live
XFS volume again.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

unittests: add fstype to _addVol

It was not possible to easily create a volume with a specific filesystem
before in the mock data. Fix that.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

unittests: allow to mount a mock volume after its creation

Add a new _mountVol mock function and modify the existing _addVol to use
it (so we avoid code duplicity, as most of the new function was od
    _addVol before).

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: do not use xfs_db for mounted filesystems, use statvfs

The xfs_db tool should not be used for a mounted filesystem, as it
bypasses various OS caches and can provide stale data.

E.g., after a resize of a xfs volume, xfs_db can report the old, pre-resize
size for about half a minute with default XFS configuration.  By using
statvfs() for mounted XFS partitions, this issue is eliminated.

RHBZ 1664652

Signed-off-by: Nitin U. Yewale <nyewale@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

master.commit_message:
bashtests: add --units h to lvs/pvs/vgs

Use --units h to avoid '<' rounding indicator that can appear in the
default unit.

From man pvs:
--units r|R|h|H|b|B|s|S|k|K|m|M|g|G|t|T|p|P|e|E

The values should not change, but if there is some small
platform-specific difference that needs rounding, it won't break the tests.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

---

Lukas, do you think that this is a good approach? Or should we change it
to --units k and demand exact sizes?

Thanks,
Jan

rfc-blacklist-storage.commit_message:
RFC: Blacklist implementation

NOTES:
This is a RFC. It works, but it is probably not yet ideal. For example,
template classes should contain some information about the blacklist.
The way it works needs some further validation. Better tests. Etc.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: filter blacklist items in run()

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: filter items in blacklist

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssmlib: add blacklist initialization and exporting to main

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

tests: add unittests for blacklist

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

tests: create bash tests for blacklist

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

misc: add Blacklist class

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

ssm: enforce python3

Change all shebangs and version-dependent calls to explicitly use
Python 3 and update the docs respectively.  This also marks the end of
python2 support.

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>

release 1.4

Signed-off-by: Jan Tulak <jtulak@redhat.com>
